description.narrative: LGBTQI Empowerment Initiative (LEI) project aim to promote potential of integrating the values of a good and productive citizen in LGBTQI people and their network, motivating them to lead a normal life by providing them a platform to develop and showcase their skills. 8 time of the community awareness raising campaign, 1000 tree will be Plant during the International Royal Festival co-organizing by the committee to contribute the climate change actions as the role model of the next generation, Gay PrideWeek Event International Human Right Day, pride Week Event in case the US-Embassy SOGI and Right session, SOGI and right training/ Refresher training, Radio Talk Show with CCHR and Media campaign to promote and reduce stigma and discrimination among LGBT1200 of most marginalized andvulnerable group of LGBTQI people will be reached and knew their HIV status at, BTB and BMC provinces. 2 capacity building on SOGI and right will be provide to 30 LGBTQI develop them

participating-org.narrative: Men#s Health Social Service Non-Governmental Organization

Vision: MHSS wants to see Cambodian people especially the most at risk population have Better access to quality of HIV and AIDS prevention, care and support, impact mitigation and related health and development opportunities. - Mission: To contribute tothe improvement of the health and well-being of most at risk Population through actively participate in the development of health services andadvocate Community and government to remove health barriers, discrimination and stigmatization. - Value: o Efficiency and Effectiveness: MHSS strives at all times to offer value for money within a process and results-oriented framework built on professionalism, social responsibility, and sustainability. o Learning and Sharing: MHSS's will join the research are utilized and disseminated to build the knowledge of all stakeholders. Evidence-based of research, innovates and pilot's new ideas, and incorporates knowledge and best practices into all of our work. MHSS's will contribute and join the research are utilizedand disseminated to build the knowledge of all stakeholders. o Good Governance: MHSS exists for the benefit of the communities it serves, and as such, communicates and operates transparently and with accountability. MHSS helps build the capacity of communities and other network to develop these practices as well o Collaboration and Partnership: MHSS Strongly believes that complex issues benefit from the input of multiple stakeholders who hold a range of perspectives. MHSS has benefitted as a result ofthe relationships formed with communities, organizations, Donors and government bodies. o Equal Gender: MHSS promotes equitable access to services, inclusive input, and leadership at all levels.The MHSS team works to decrease gender disparities in society, and to end violence and power inequalities within relationships o Diversity: MHSS supports the rights of KP, Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender <(>&<)> Intersex (LGBTI), and other vulnerable groups in order to build stronger awareness and respect for diversity. MHSS also influences policies that promote and build inclusivity for all
Men's Health Social Service (MHSS) is a local NGO established by group of MSM and TG in community and official registered in 2004 as local and non-profit organization. Therewere 9 branch offices in Phnom Penh, Battambang, Banteay Meanchey/PoyPet, Kampong Chhnang, Kampong Thom, Pursat and Pailin, Kampong Spue and Prey Veng provinces. Goal: Contribute to eliminating new HIV infection, stigma and discrimination, strengtheninghealth system and achieving universal health coverage (UHC) in Cambodia. Their vision, MHSS aspire to all Cambodian people that support community ownership and empowerment where all people have equitable access to the quality HIVand comprehensive healthservices and sustainable development opportunity. And mission, To continue to bea leader in the HIV response while addressing wider health and development need of Cambodia people.
With Funded support from the Global Fund and USAID from 2013-2018, the project lead brad MStyle and provide technical assistant to other Implementing partners in Cambodia. Experience from the previous, there were cased of stigma and discrimination related to access health service, Cases arrested of LGBTIQ by the police underimplementing the commune and village safety policy at publish garden and along the river, at Battambang, Banteaymeanchey, Seam Reab, Pursat and Phnom Penh city. To solve this problem at crossroad level, MHSS have been working closely with National and Sub-National program such as NAA, NCHADS relevant ministries, LINKAGES/FHI360, UN agencies, PHDs/PASP, police inspectors, health service providers and EE owner, media, conduct regular consultations at provincial level to bring the issues to discuss and solve the problem with technical support from the National level.
Beyond of enhance of enabling environment through national and Sub-national consultation meeting, MHSS had, round table discussion, meeting with key enforcement and parents, publish medias, community awareness raising campaign to share their experience and success storyof reduce stigma and discrimination from their family and community. From yearto year to year, the case of arrested by police, stigma and discrimination and violence and barrier of LGBTIQ people have been reduced and recognized from national and sub-national program this we need to reinforce this best practice from the previous funded by USIAD, from 2013-2018, to Empowerment Grant for filling the gapes and supplement of potential activities of the current funding of the global Fund Grant.

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation

description.narrative: Civil society actors transformed and strengthened,
CSO actors that build trust and work in inclusive way in coalitions
CSO that improved their acccess to flexible resources to actively address, reclaim and navigate civic space offline and online, involving and considering esp. marginalized groups
CSOs that strengthened the links with their constituencies due to changed ways of working
CSOs with improved risk strategies and improves support when a civic space crisis occurs
CSOs with increased women and youth in leadership positions
informal movements/individuals with access to flexible resources to address, reclaim and navigate civic space offline and/or online
